title: General
stimulusHtml:
This question is scored on a 6-point scale:

6

An excellent, well-organized essay which includes a convincing discussion of Dido’s psychological/emotional conﬂict by making use of references from the text to her past, present, and future. The discussion contains liberal use of speciﬁc, appropriate references from the Latin text, with accurate translation or paraphrase, which support the analysis. Occasional mistakes need not spoil the general impression of the essay. A strong thesis underlies and ties the essay together.

5

A very good essay which includes a fairly persuasive discussion of Dido‘s psychological/emotional conﬂict. A number of references from the text to Dido’s past, present, and future are used to support the analysis.

4

A passing score: a "bare bones" response which contains an adequate but superficial discussion of Dido‘s psychological/emotional conﬂict. Essay tends to be descriptive rather than analytical. References are made to Dido’s past, present, and future. These may be scanty, not optimally chosen and/or unevenly discussed. Or, there is a good discussion of two of the time periods, with good Latin support.

3

Essay merely paraphrases the passage without discussion of how the text conveys Dido‘s confusion. Or, there is a fairly good discussion of Dido’s conﬂict without support from the text. References to the time periods are incomplete or unsupported by references from the text.

2

An effort is made to discuss Dido’s confusion, but Latin support is sparse, incorrect, and/or ineffectual. Some correct information is given.

1

Disorganized effort at discussion of Dido‘s confusion, based largely on information given in the question. Textual references (if any) show no indication of an understanding of the Latin. Some bit of correct information must be given beyond what is given in the question.

0

An answer which is totally irrelevant or totally incorrect.
descriptions: An answer which is totally irrelevant or totally incorrect.

Disorganized effort at discussion of Dido‘s confusion, based largely on information given in the question. Textual references (if any) show no indication of an understanding of the Latin. Some bit of correct information must be given beyond what is given in the question.

References are made to Dido’s past, present, and future. These may be scanty, not optimally chosen and/or unevenly discussed. Or, there is a good discussion of two of the time periods, with good Latin support.

A very good essay which includes a fairly persuasive discussion of Dido‘s psychological/emotional conﬂict. A number of references from the text to Dido’s past, present, and future are used to support the analysis.

An excellent, well-organized essay which includes a convincing discussion of Dido’s psychological/emotional conﬂict by making use of references from the text to her past, present, and future. The discussion contains liberal use of speciﬁc, appropriate references from the Latin text, with accurate translation or paraphrase, which support the analysis. Occasional mistakes need not spoil the general impression of the essay. A strong thesis underlies and ties the essay together.
